text: Nice idea! It's always useful to have a notepad :slightly_smiling_face: For a few reasons:
1) You should prepare your questions, so you can have them written down (just in case you forget)
2) Then, like you said... you can jot down some points they mention when they respond (I really like that idea!)
3) You can use the notepad for tough questions*

*if you recall from the document I sent you about "finding time" to answer - if you ask for a minute or two to think, you can write down / structure your answer before you respond in your notebook :+1:
Ok, I'm going to send across another short document soon for you to have a look over :+1:

I studied Economics... and it was good! I didn't know what to do... or what I wanted to do after... so I chose it because I thought it kept as many doors open as possible. However, I learned that it doesn't matter what course you do, as the vast majority of companies are looking for intelligent, hard working people - so if you've done a degree in "Classics and Ancient History" or "Computer Science" you can still change your mind after and work in something completely different!

*I worked with a guy who studied Classics and Ancient History and became a IT Consultant... and someone else who studied Computer Science and became an English Teacher... in fact, a few other of my friends made similar U-turns :smile:

And why did I become an interview coach? To be honest.... I kind of fell into it! I can't say it was my dream, but it started when I helped my sister prepare for an interview and she told me I should "sell it!" I then realised I already had a lot of experience working with HR professionals, and having had interviewed lots of people myself, started to build it into a business. So that's how I got to where I am today :slightly_smiling_face:
Let me know when you've had a chance to read it - if you have any questions, let me know :slightly_smiling_face:
